content: <articles>    <article xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink/">   <front>     <article-meta>       <title-group>         <article-title>Software Defined Networking for CommunityNetwork Testbeds</article-title>       </title-group>       <contrib-group>         <contrib contrib-type="author">           <name>             <surname>Dimogerontakis</surname>             <given-names>Emmanouil</given-names>           </name>         </contrib>         <contrib contrib-type="author">           <name>             <surname>Vilata</surname>             <given-names>Ivan</given-names>           </name>         </contrib>         <contrib contrib-type="author">           <name>             <surname>Navarro</surname>             <given-names>Leandro</given-names>           </name>         </contrib>       </contrib-group>       <pub-date pub-type="pub">         <year>2013</year>       </pub-date>       <self-uri xlink:href="http://zenodo.org/record/7547"/>       <self-uri xlink:href="http://research.ac.upc.edu/CNBuB2013/"/>       <self-uri xlink:href="http://zenodo.org/record/7547/files/CNBuB_CONFINE_SDN_Paper.pdf"/>       <self-uri xlink:href="http://zenodo.org/record/7547/files/CNBuB_CONFINE_SDN_Paper.png?subformat=icon-90"/>     </article-meta>     <abstract><p>Wireless Community Networks have received increasing attention the latest years. In an effort to set the cornerstone for an internet without central authorities and &nbsp;monopolies,&nbsp;network engineers throughout the world have started creating&nbsp;community networks. To enhance this effort, Community-lab,&nbsp;a wireless community networks testbed, was created allowing&nbsp;researchers to experiment with new protocols and applications&nbsp;in a realistic environment. Nevertheless, this testbed does not offer&nbsp;the ability to perform L2 experiments. To address this gap, we&nbsp;developed a platform that allows Community-Lab researchers to&nbsp;perform L2 experiments. Moreover, we decided to reach our goal&nbsp;using Software Defined Networking(SDN) techniques, due to the&nbsp;attention they received lately and their promise for a complete&nbsp;networking solution. Overall, we propose an architecture that&nbsp;allows researchers to perform L2 experiments in a generic&nbsp;community networks testbed. To prove the feasibility of our&nbsp;archtecture we implemented it for Community-Lab using the&nbsp;OpenFlow SDN protocol, enabling researchers to manage the L2&nbsp;topology of their experiments.</p></abstract>   </front>   <article-type>user-confine</article-type> </article>   </articles>
